11.P. To which Deva is the Rohini Nakshatra assigned? _A. It is assigned to Payavaideva, 12.P. To which Deva is the Santhana Nakshatra assigned?
A. It is assigned to Soma Deva, 13.P. To which Deva is the Adda Nakshatra assigned?
A. It is assigned to Rudra Deva, 14.P. To which Deva is the Punarvasu Nakshatra assigned?
A. It is assigned to Aditi Deva, 15.P. To which Deva is the Pusya Nakshatra assigned?
A. It is assigned to Bahasai Deva, 16.P. To which Deva is the Ashlesha Nakshatra assigned? A. It is assigned to Sappa Deva, 17.P. To which Deva is the Maha Nakshatra assigned?
A. It is assigned to Piti Deva, 18.P. To which Deva is the Purva Phalguni Nakshatra assigned?
A. It is assigned to Bhaga Deva, 19.P. To which Deva is the Uttara Phalguni Nakshatra assigned? - A. It is assigned to Ajjama Deva, 20.P. To which Deva is the Hasta Nakshatra assigned?
A. It is assigned to Suviya Deva, 21.P. To which Deva is the Chitra Nakshatra assigned?
A. It is assigned to Tathe Deva, 22.P. To which Deva is the Swati Nakshatra assigned?
A. It is assigned to Vau Deva,
1. Prajapati is the Deva with the name Brahma, and he bears all the synonyms of Brahma, hence the famous Brahma, etc. 2. Soma is the Moon, hence the famous Saumya, Chandramas, etc. 3. Rudra is Shiva, hence the famous Raudra, Kalini, etc. 4. Pitar is the name of a Deva, 5. Aryama is a specific Deva, 6. Savita is the Sun, 7. Tvasta is a Deva with the name Tvastra, hence the famous Tvastri, Chitra, etc.

## The Tenth Prabhruta [Fourteenth Prabhruta-Prabhruta]

**Question:** What are the names of the 48 days?

**Answer:** There are 15 days in each fortnight, named as follows:

* **Days:** 1. Padivaya, 2. Bitiya, 3. Taiya, 4. Chauthi, 5. Panchmi, 6. Chhathi, 7. Sattami, 8. Athamo, 9. Navami, 10. Dasami, 11. Ekkharasi, 12. Barasi, 13. Terasi, 14. Chaudas, 15. Pannares.

* **Names:** 1. Puvange, 2. Siddhamanorame, 3. Y Tattho, 4. Manoharo Cheva, 5. Jasabhadde, 6. Jasodhara, 7. Savvakamasamiddhe Ti Ya, 8. Inde Muddhabhisitte Ya, 9. Somanas, 10. Dhananjay, 11. Ya Boddhvave, 12. Aththasiddhe, 13. Abhijaye, 14. Accasana, 15. Satangaye, 16. Aggivise, 17. Uvasame.

**Question:** What are the names of the 48 Raio?

**Answer:** There are 15 Raio in each fortnight, named as follows:

* **Raio:** 1. Padivaraai, 2. Bitiyaraai, 3. Tatiyaraai, 4. Chauthiraai, 5. Panchmiraai, 6. Chhathiraai, 7. Satmiraai, 8. Athmiraai, 9. Navmiraai, 10. Dasmiraai, 11. Ekkharasiraai, 12. Barasiraai, 13. Terasiraai, 14. Chaussiraai, 15. Pannaressiraai.

* **Names:** 1. Uttama Ya, 2. Sunakhatta, 3. Elavaccha, 4. Jasodhara, 5. Somanas Cheva Taha, 6. Sirisambhuta Ya Boddhva, 7. Vijaya Ya, 8. Vejayanti, 9. Jayanti, 10. Aparajia Ya, 11. Gachcha Ya, 12. Samahara Cheva Taha, 13. Te Ya Taha Ya, 14. Atitaya, 15. Devanandanirati.

[Surya Prajnapti Sutra]
P. 11. In which gotra is the Rohini nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Gotama gotra. P. 12. In which gotra is the Santhana nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Bharadvaja gotra. P. 13. In which gotra is the Adha nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Lahicchaayana gotra. P. 14. In which gotra is the Punarvasu nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Vasishtha gotra. P. 15. In which gotra is the Pushya nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Ujjayana gotra. P. 16. In which gotra is the Ashlesha nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Mandavvaayana gotra. P. 17. In which gotra is the Magha nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Pingayana gotra. P. 18. In which gotra is the Purva Phalguni nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Govallayana gotra. P. 19. In which gotra is the Uttara Phalguni nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Kasava gotra. P. 20. In which gotra is the Hasta nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Kosiya gotra. P. 21. In which gotra is the Chitra nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Dabbiyaana gotra. P. 22. In which gotra is the Swati nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Chamarachcha gotra. P. 23. In which gotra is the Visakha nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Sungayana gotra. P. 24. In which gotra is the Anuradha nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Golavvaayana gotra. P. 25. In which gotra is the Jyeshta nakshatra established? A. It is established in the Tigicchaayana gotra.

P. 26. In which gotra is the Mula Nakshatra? A. It is in the Kachayan gotra. P. 27. In which gotra is the Purvashadha Nakshatra? A. It is in the Vazhiayan gotra. P. 28. In which gotra is the Uttarashadha Nakshatra? A. It is in the Vagyavach gotra.
P. Thus, venerable sir! In which gotra are the twenty-eight Nakshatras?
Goyama! They are in the Moggalayan gotra, the planets are - 1. Moggalayan, 2. Sankhayan, 3. Agga-bhava, 4. Kasinalle. Then 5. Ja-ukanne, 6. Dhananjaye and Boddhvave. ||1|| 7. Pusayan, 8. Assayan, 9. Bhaggave, 10. Aggi-ve. 11. Goam, 12. Bharada, 13. Lohi-che, 14. Vasite. ||2|| 15. Omjayana, 16. Mandavayana, 17. Pingayana, 18. Govalle. 19. Kasava, 20. Kosiya, 21. Dabbiya, 22. Chamarachcha, 23. Sungaya. ||3|| 24. Golavayana, 25. Tegicchayana, 26. Kachayan is the Mula. 27. Then Majjiayana, 28. Vaggavach is the gotra. ||4|| - Jambu. Vakkh. 7, S. 160

**Nakshatra Food for Success**

**51. P.**
**U.**
**From the tenth [to the seventeenth] Nakshatra**

**1.**
**2.**
**3.**
**4.**
**How are these foods?**  It is said that:
**In the twenty-eighth Nakshatra:**
* **Krittika:**  Success is achieved by eating curd.
* **Rohini:** Success is achieved by eating Vasa-mansa (meat of a particular animal).
* **Mrigashira:** Success is achieved by eating deer meat.
* **Aardra:** Success is achieved by eating salt.
* **Punarvasu:** Success is achieved by eating ghee.
* **Pushya:** Success is achieved by drinking milk.
* **Ashlesha:** Success is achieved by eating Divaga-mansa (meat of a particular animal).
* **Magha:** Success is achieved by eating Kasoti (a type of food).
**5.**
**6.**
**7.**
**8.**
**9.** **Purva Phalguni:** Success is achieved by eating frog meat.
**10.** **Uttara Phalguni:** Success is achieved by eating Nakhhi-mansa (meat of a particular animal).
**11.** **Hasta:** Success is achieved by eating Vatthani (a type of food).
**12.** **Chitra:** Success is achieved by eating Mugga Suvena (a type of food).
**13.** **Swati:** Success is achieved by eating fruits.
**14.** **Visakha:** Success is achieved by eating Asitti (a type of food).
**15.** **Anuradha:** Success is achieved by eating Misakur (a type of food).
**16.** **Jyeshta:** Success is achieved by eating Kolatti (a type of food).
**17.** **Moola:** Success is achieved by eating Mulapanna (a type of food).
**18.** **Purva Ashadha:** Success is achieved by eating Amalag-sarira (a type of food).
**19.** **Uttara Ashadha:** Success is achieved by eating Bille (a type of food).
**1.** **Rohini:** Success is achieved by eating Chamsa-mansa (a type of meat).

**A.S. Samiti published this text on page 151 (with variations).**

## From the tenth Prabhruta to the seventeenth Prabhruta Prabhruta:

20. They perform the Bhocca ceremony with flowers on the Abhijit Nakshatra.
21. They perform the Bhocca ceremony with milk on the Savana Nakshatra.
22. They perform the Bhocca ceremony with juice on the Dhanishta Nakshatra.
23. They perform the Bhocca ceremony with Tuvari on the Satabhisha Nakshatra.
24. They perform the Bhocca ceremony with the remains of the previous day's food on the Pushya Nakshatra.
25. They perform the Bhocca ceremony with boar meat on the Uttara Nakshatra.
26. They perform the Bhocca ceremony with aquatic animal meat on the Revati Nakshatra.
27. They perform the Bhocca ceremony with bird meat or turtle meat on the Asvini Nakshatra.
28. They perform the Bhocca ceremony with sesame and rice on the Bharani Nakshatra.

1. Kulmasa, rice, Masha, cow's yogurt, ghee, milk, buffalo meat, its blood, payasa, sesame, Marg, Shasha, sixty types of Priyangu, puffed rice, and colored eggs are considered good fruits. || 84 ||
Karm, Sarika, Godhika, sesame, Shalya, Havishya, horse's ghee, Krisara, Mudga, and ground barley are also considered good. || 85 ||
Fish, colored food, and yogurt food are also considered good. Thus, a wise person should consider what is edible and what is not edible and eat accordingly. || 85 ||

[ 121
-
This seventeenth Prabhruta Prabhruta in the Muhurta Chintamani, the chapter on travel, is not actually taught by the Bhagavan, but seems to have been added by someone else. This style of language is not found in the Bhagavan's teachings. For example, in some places, the third case plural is used, such as "Kattiyahim, Rohinihim, Addahim," while in other places, the third case singular is used, such as "Punavvasuna, Pussehena, Addaae." Also, in the context of food, the third case is used in some places, while the second case is used in others. For example, "Dahina Bhocca, Baniyena Bhocca, Khirena Bhocca" uses the third case, while "Vasabha Mansa Bhocca, Miga Mansa Bhocca, Deeva Mansa Bhocca" uses the second case. This inconsistent use of language suggests that this section was not taught by the Bhagavan.

Furthermore, in some places, the consumption of land, water, and air animals is mentioned as a cause for success. This is completely inappropriate, as the Bhagavan, who teaches the protection of the six bodies and the six-bodied beings, would never advocate for the consumption of meat. Such teachings are not found anywhere in the scriptures. Therefore, it is certain that this section is not part of the Bhagavan's teachings.

However, there is another logical reason. In the scriptures, the counting of the Nakshatras always starts from the Abhijit Nakshatra, as it is the first Nakshatra of the Yuga. In this scripture, the first Prabhruta Prabhruta of the tenth Prabhruta begins with the following sutra:

"How do you know that the objects are arranged in this way? What is the basis for this arrangement? They said, "There are five different interpretations here. They said, "All the Nakshatras, starting from Krittika and ending with Bharani, are one." || 1 ||

This is the first interpretation of the other Tirthankaras. They believe that the Nakshatras, starting from Krittika and ending with Bharani, are one. There are five such interpretations of the other Tirthankaras. The second interpretation is: "All the Nakshatras, starting from Magha and ending with Ashlesha, are one." || 2 ||

The third interpretation is: "All the Nakshatras, starting from Dhanishta and ending with Shravana, are one." || 3 ||

The fourth interpretation is: "All the Nakshatras, starting from Ashvini and ending with Revati, are one." || 4 ||

The fifth interpretation is: "All the Nakshatras, starting from Bharani and ending with Ashvini, are one." || 5 ||

After refuting all these five interpretations, the Bhagavan presents his own view:

## The Tenth Prabhruta [Eighteenth Prabhruta-Prabhruta]

In one Yuga, the number of solar and lunar cycles is 52. P.K. How are these cycles? Answer: There are two types of cycles here, as follows: 1. Solar cycles, 2. Lunar cycles. P.K. How are the lunar cycles? Answer: In a Yuga of five years, 

1. The moon joins with the Abhijit Nakshatra for 77 cycles,
2. The moon joins with the Savana Nakshatra for 77 cycles, and so on, until 3-28. The moon joins with the Uttara Ashadha Nakshatra for 77 cycles. P.K. How are the solar cycles? Answer: In a Yuga of five years, 

1. The sun joins with the Abhijit Nakshatra for five cycles, and so on, until 2-28. The sun joins with the Uttara Ashadha Nakshatra for five cycles.

"We say this - all the Nakshatras from Abhijit to Uttara Ashadha are established, as follows: Abhijit, Savana, until Uttara Ashadha."

The commentary by Malayagiri Suri on this is as follows:

The beginning of the Yuga starts on the first day of the bright fortnight of Shravana month, when the moon joins with the Abhijit Nakshatra at the time of the Balavakarna. This is stated in the Jyotish Karndaka:

"On the first day of the bright fortnight of Shravana month, the moon joins with the Abhijit Nakshatra."

"In all cases, the beginning of the Yuga is considered to be the time of the moon's conjunction." This is stated by Bharata, the great scholar. Thus, the Nakshatras from Abhijit onwards are established, considering the moon's conjunction as the beginning of all specific times.

Here, the Nakshatras from Krittika to Bharani are considered to be the first by the early Tirthankaras. According to their view, this Prabhruta-Prabhruta is seen. This is not the view of the Bhagavan, as it is clear that in this seventeenth Prabhruta-Prabhruta, the Bhagavan's form cannot be established. This is enough elaboration.

- Chandraprajnapti Prakashka Commentary

## Dashama Prabhruta
[Nineteenth Prabhruta Prabhruta]  A year has 53 months. P. How are those months? A. Thus it is said, U.  A year has twelve months,
and they are named in two ways, as follows: 1. Loiya, 2. Lo Uttariya.  The Loiya names are: 1. Savane, 2. Bhaddave, 3. Asoe, 4. Kattie, 5. Maggasire, 6. Pose, 7. Mahe, 8. Phaggune, 9. Chette, 10. Vesah, 11. Jette, 12. Asadhe.  The Lo Uttariya names are:  - 1. Abhinandane, 2. Supaithe, 3. Vijaye, 4. Piivaddhane, 5. Sejanse, 6. Siviya, 7. Sisire, 8. Hemvan. ||1|| 9. Navame Vasanta Mase,
10. Dasame Kusuma Sambhave, 11. Ekadasame Nidaho, 12. Vanavirohi ya Barase. ||2||
1. Jambu. Vakkh. 7, Su. 153

##  Types of Years and Their Characteristics

**54.**
**Q.** What are the types of years?
**A.** There are five types of years: 1. Nakshatra-Samvatsara, 2. Yuga-Samvatsara, 3. Paman-Samvatsara, 4. Lakshan-Samvatsara, 5. Sanichchar-Samvatsara.

**55.**
**1. Nakshatra-Samvatsara:**
**a.** There are twelve Nakshatras in a Nakshatra-Samvatsara: 1. Savana, 2. Bhadrava, 3. Asouya, 4. Kattika, 5. Maggasira, 6. Pousa, 7. Mahe, 8. Phagguniya, 9. Chitta, 10. Vaisaha, 11. Jetta, 12. Asadha.
**b.** The entire Nakshatra Mandala is completed in twelve years by the Bahussai Mahaggha.

**56.**
**2. Yuga-Samvatsara:**
**a.** There are five types of Yuga-Samvatsara: 1. Chanda, 2. Chanda, 3. Abhivaddiya, 4. Chanda, 5. Abhivaddiya.
**b.** The first Chanda-Samvatsara has 24 Pavas, the second Chanda-Samvatsara has 24 Pavas, the Abhivaddiya-Samvatsara has 26 Pavas, the fourth Chanda-Samvatsara has 24 Pavas, and the fifth Abhivaddiya-Samvatsara has 26 Pavas.
**c.** Thus, in a Yuga of five years, there are 124 Pavas in total.

**57-58.**
**3. Paman-Samvatsara:**
**a.** There are five types of Paman-Samvatsara: 1. Nakshatra, 2. Chanda, 3. Udu, 4. Aicha, 5. Abhivaddiya.

4. Lakshana Samvatsara's Characteristics -
_In Lakshana Samvatsara, five types are established, namely - 1. Nakshatra, 2. Chandra, 3. Udu, 4. Aiccha, 5. Abhivaddhiya. 5. Sanichchara Samvatsara's Characteristics -
In Sanichchara Samvatsara, twenty-eight types are established, namely - 1. Abhiyi, 2. Savana, 3. Dhanishtha, 4. Satabhisaya, 5. Puvvapoṭṭavaya, 6. Uttarapoṭṭavaya, 7. Revati, 8. Assiṇi, 9. Bharani, 10. Kattiya, 11. Rohini, 12. Sanṭhaṇā, 13. Adda, 14. Punavassu, 15. Pussa, 16. Asseṣa, 17. Maha, 18. Puvvafagguni, 19. Uttarafagguni, 20. Hatthe, 21. Chitta, 22. Sai, 23. Visaha, 24. Anuraha, 25. Jettha, 26. Mule, 27. Puvvasaḍha, 28. Uttarasadha. In Sanichchara, the entire Nakshatra Mandala is completed in thirty years. Gatha - Nakshatra Samvatsara Lakshana - All Nakshatras rise together, all Udu's culminate together. There is no absence,
Many Nakshatras rise. ||1|| Chandra Samvatsara Lakshana - The moon rises together with the full moon,
The Nakshatras rise in an uneven manner.
There is much rain,
That is called Chandra Samvatsara. ||2|| 3. Udu (Karma) Samvatsara Lakshana -
The uneven ones culminate,
The flowers and fruits are not ripe.
The season does not stay properly,
That is called Karma Samvatsara. ||3|| Aiccha Samvatsara Lakshana -
It gives the taste of earth and water,
And the flowers and fruits in Aiccha.
Even with little rain,
The crops are fully ripened. ||4|| Abhivaddhiya Samvatsara Lakshana -
The Aiccha's influence is seen,
The moments, seconds, and days culminate.
It fills the earth with dust,
That is called Abhivaddhiya. ||5||
1. Thaṇam. 5, U. 3, Su. 460 2. Thaṇam. 5, U. 3, Su. 460

## Tenth Prabhruta
[Twenty-first Prabhruta Prabhruta]  The direction of the Nakshatras - 59. P. Ta, how is the direction of the Tejo?  Ahiye tti vaejja, U. Tatha khalu imao panch padivattao pannattio, tanjaha -

There, they said - 1. Ta, the seven Nakshatras starting from Katta are in the East direction, some said.
Some, however, said - 2. Ta, the seven Nakshatras starting from Maha are in the East direction, some said.
Some, however, said - 3. Ta, the seven Nakshatras starting from Dhanishtha are in the East direction, some said.
Some, however, said - 4. Ta, the seven Nakshatras starting from Ashlesha are in the East direction, some said.
Some, however, said - 5. Ta, the seven Nakshatras starting from Bharani are in the East direction, some said.

1. There, those who said - (a) Ta, the seven Nakshatras starting from Katta are in the East direction, they said, tanjaha -
1. Katta, 2. Rohini, 3. Mrigashirsha, 4. Ardra, 5. Punarvasu, 6. Pushya, 7. Ashlesha. (b) The seven Nakshatras starting from Maha are in the South direction, tanjaha -
1. Maha, 2. Purva Phalguni, 3. Uttara Phalguni, 4. Hasta, 5. Chitra, 6. Swati, 7. Visakha. (c) The seven Nakshatras starting from Anuradha are in the West direction, tanjaha -
1. Anuradha, 2. Jyeshta, 3. Mula, 4. Purva Ashadha, 5. Uttara Ashadha, 6. Abhijit, 7. Shravana. (d) The seven Nakshatras starting from Dhanishtha are in the North direction, tanjaha -
1. Dhanishtha, 2. Shatabhisha, 3. Purva Bhadrapada, 4. Uttara Bhadrapada, 5. Revati, 6. Ashlesha,

S. 7, Su. 8, 9, 10, 11, the sutras given here are indicative of other beliefs, but there is no such sentence in these sutras that would allow a common reader to know these sutras as other beliefs. Although the first constellation in the Jain Agamas is Abhijit and the last constellation is Uttara Ashadha, how is it possible to know the different orders of the different constellations that changed at different times without studying the Agamas?

## From the tenth Prabhruta [twenty-second Prabhruta-Prabhruta]
## Of the Nakshatras, the Saruva-Paruva-na
## 60. P. So, how is that Nakshatra-vijaya? Tell me.
## U.
So, in Jambudvipa, in the island, of all the islands, of all the seas, of all the oceans, of all the continents, of all the mountains, up to one hundred thousand yojanas in length and breadth, three hundred thousand yojanas, sixteen thousand, two hundred and twenty-seven hundred yojanas, three kosas, twenty-eight dhanus, thirteen angulas, and a little more than half an angula, it is declared by calculation.

[131
From the tenth Prabhruta to the twenty-second Prabhruta-Prabhruta]
[131
There are two types of Nakshatras, those that are in conjunction with the Sun for twenty-one Muhurtas in a day and night, and those that are in conjunction with the Sun for twelve Muhurtas in thirteen days and nights.
a. The Nakshatras that are in conjunction with the Sun for twenty-one Muhurtas in a day and night are twelve in number, namely:
1. Two Satabhisha, 2. Two Bharani, 3. Two Adda, 4. Two Assesa, 5. Two Sati, 6. Two Jettha.
b. The Nakshatras that are in conjunction with the Sun for twelve Muhurtas in thirteen days and nights are thirty in number, namely:
1. Two Savana, 2. Two Dhanishtha, 3. Two Purvabhadrapada, 4. Two Revati, 5. Two Asvini, 6. Two Kattta, 7. Two Santhana, 8. Two Pushya, 9. Two Maha, 10. Two Purva Phalguni, 11. Two Hasta, 12. Two Chitta, 13. Two Anuradha, 14. Two Mula, 15. Two Purvashadha.
c. The Nakshatras that are in conjunction with the Sun for three Muhurtas in twenty days and nights are twelve in number, namely:
1. Two Uttaraphalguni, 2. Two Rohini, 3. Two Punarvasu, 4. Two Uttaraphalguni, 5. Two Visakha, 6. Two Uttarashadha.
The boundary extent of the Nakshatra Mandala is 61.
Q. How is this boundary extent? Please tell me.
A. a. There are Nakshatras whose boundary extent is 630, 76 parts out of 30 parts.
b. There are Nakshatras whose boundary extent is 1076 parts out of 30 parts.
c. There are Nakshatras whose boundary extent is 2076 parts out of 30 parts.
d. There are Nakshatras whose boundary extent is 3076 parts out of 30 parts.
Q. a. Which Nakshatras have a boundary extent of 630, 76 parts out of 30 parts?
b. Which Nakshatras have a boundary extent of 1076 parts out of 30 parts?
c. Which Nakshatras have a boundary extent of 2076 parts out of 30 parts?
d. Which Nakshatras have a boundary extent of 3076 parts out of 30 parts?
A. a. The Nakshatras whose boundary extent is 630, 76 parts out of 30 parts are two in number.

**b.**  Those stars, whose boundary diameter is 76 parts and 30 parts of a thousand and five, are twelve in number, namely: 1. Two Satabhisha, 2. Two Bharani, 3. Two Adda, 4. Two Assesa, 5. Two Sati, 6. Two Jettha.

**c.** Those stars, whose boundary diameter is 76 parts and 30 parts of two thousand and ten, are thirty in number, namely: 1. Two Savana, 2. Two Dhanishtha, 3. Two Purvabhadrapada, 4. Two Revati, 5. Two Asvini, 6. Two Kattta, 7. Two Santhana, 8. Two Pushya, 9. Two Maha, 10. Two Purva Phalguni, 11. Two Hasta, 12. Two Chitta, 13. Two Anuradha, 14. Two Mula, 15. Two Purvashadha.

**d.** Those stars, whose boundary diameter is 76 parts and 30 parts of three thousand and fifteen, are twelve in number, namely: 1. Two Uttarapotthapada, 2. Two Rohini, 3. Two Punarvasu, 4. Two Uttara Phalguni, 5. Two Visakha, 6. Two Uttarashadha.

**The conjunction of the Moon with the stars - 62.**

**p.** **k.**  In these fifty-six stars, which of them are in conjunction with the Moon at the time of its rising?

**b.** In these fifty-six stars, which of them are in conjunction with the Moon at the time of its setting?

**c.** In these fifty-six stars, which of them are in conjunction with the Moon when it enters and exits?

**u.** **k.** In these fifty-six stars, none of them are in conjunction with the Moon at the time of its rising.

**b.** None of them are in conjunction with the Moon at the time of its setting.

**c.** None of them are in conjunction with the Moon when it enters and exits, because there are two eclipses.

Therefore, these two eclipses occur thirty-four times each, both during the new moon and the full moon.

**The conjunction of the Moon with the full moon - 63.**

Therefore, these twenty-eight full moons and twenty-eight new moons are established.

**1.** **p.** In these five years, on which full moon does the Moon join the first star?

**u.** On the same full moon on which the Moon joins the last star in the last of these twenty-eight full moons.

**1.** Therefore, from the position of the full moon, the last twenty-eighth full moon, from the position of the end of the full moon, the circle is divided by 124.

The mandala should be divided into 32 parts by 24 hundred, 64 parts should be considered for the first full moon, 2. Q. In which country does the moon appear on the second full moon of these five years? A. In the country where the moon appears on the first full moon, the mandala should be divided into 32 parts by 24 hundred, 64 parts should be considered for the second full moon, 3. Q. In which country does the moon appear on the third full moon of these five years? A. In the country where the moon appears on the second full moon, the mandala should be divided into 32 parts by 24 hundred, 64 parts should be considered for the third full moon, 4. Q. In which country does the moon appear on the twelfth full moon of these five years?
A. In the country where the moon appears on the third full moon, the mandala should be divided into 180 parts by 24 hundred, 64 parts should be considered for the twelfth full moon, thus, according to this calculation, the mandala should be divided into 32 parts by 24 hundred, 64 parts should be considered for each full moon in each country. 5. Q. In which country does the moon appear on the last, 62nd full moon of these five years?
A. In Jambudvipa, the mandala should be divided into 27 parts by 24 hundred, 64 parts should be considered for the southern quadrant, 18 parts should be considered for the western quadrant, 20 parts should be considered for the northern quadrant, and the remaining 3 parts and 2 kalas should be considered for the eastern quadrant, the moon appears on the last, 62nd full moon in this region. 1. 'Two hundred and eighty parts' means,
The twelfth full moon after the third full moon is the ninth full moon,
Then, by multiplying nine by ninety, two hundred and eighty are obtained. 2. 1. 'Jambudvipa' etc.
In the phrase 'Jambudvipa', the word 'dvipa' is used in the sense of 'island', and the word 'prachina' is used in the sense of 'ancient', and the word 'apachina' is used in the sense of 'modern'. Therefore, the meaning is that the moon appears in the north-east, south-west, north-south, east-west, and south-north directions, and the mandala should be divided into 24 hundred parts, and then divided into four parts, and then the southern quadrant should be divided into 27 parts, and then the western quadrant should be divided into 18 parts, and then the northern quadrant should be divided into 20 parts, and then the remaining 3 parts and 2 kalas should be considered for the eastern quadrant, and the moon appears on the last, 62nd full moon in this region. - Commentary

##  [134]
[Surya Prajnapti Sutra]

**1. Q:** In these five years, on which day of the full moon does the sun enter the first constellation?
**A:** The sun enters the last constellation on the full moon day. From that full moon day, the circle is divided into 240 parts, and the first constellation is 9/240 of the circle. The sun enters the first constellation on that full moon day.

**2. Q:** In these five years, on which day of the full moon does the sun enter the second constellation?
**A:** The sun enters the first constellation on the full moon day. From that full moon day, the circle is divided into 240 parts, and the second constellation is 9/240 of the circle. The sun enters the second constellation on that full moon day.

**3. Q:** In these five years, on which day of the full moon does the sun enter the third constellation?
**A:** The sun enters the second constellation on the full moon day. From that full moon day, the circle is divided into 240 parts, and the third constellation is 9/240 of the circle. The sun enters the third constellation on that full moon day.

**4. Q:** In these five years, on which day of the full moon does the sun enter the twelfth constellation?
**A:** The sun enters the third constellation on the full moon day. From that full moon day, the circle is divided into 240 parts, and the twelfth constellation is 84/240 of the circle. The sun enters the twelfth constellation on that full moon day.

Thus, in this way, from each full moon day, the circle is divided into 240 parts, and the sun enters each constellation on the corresponding full moon day.

**5. Q:** In these five years, on which day of the full moon does the sun enter the last constellation?
**A:** The sun enters the last constellation on the full moon day. From that full moon day, the circle is divided into 240 parts, and the last constellation is 27/240 of the circle.

**1. '84/240'**
The twelfth full moon is nine days after the third full moon.
Then, 9 is multiplied by 9, resulting in 84.

**2.** The last full moon of the western era is the 62nd full moon.
From that point, the circle is divided into 240 parts.
The sun enters each constellation after 9/240 of the circle.
Then, 9 is multiplied by 62, resulting in 558.
Then, 558 is divided by 240, resulting in 2.325.
This means that the sun completes 2 full circles and enters the 33rd constellation.

Twenty-eight parts are to be divided by twenty-six, eighteen parts are to be divided by eighteen, in these parts, two are to be divided by two.
The southern quadrant of the mandala is not complete. Here, the sun is seen on the last full moon day. The moon is seen on the new moon day. 65. P. So, on which day of the year will the new moon be seen in which country?
A. In the country where the moon is seen on the last full moon day, the mandala of the new moon day is to be divided by twenty-four, thirty-two parts are to be divided by thirty-two. Here, the moon will be seen on the first new moon day. Similarly, as the full moon days are named, so are the new moon days, such as - second, third, twelfth. So, in this way, the mandala of the new moon day is to be divided by twenty-four, thirty-two parts are to be divided by thirty-two. In those countries, the new moon will be seen on that day. P. So, on which day of the year will the last new moon be seen in which country? A. In the country where the moon is seen on the last full moon day, the mandala of the full moon day is to be divided by twenty-four, sixteen parts are to be divided by sixteen. Here, the moon will be seen on the last new moon day. The sun is seen on the new moon day.
P. So, on which day of the year will the first new moon be seen in which country? A. In the country where the sun is seen on the last new moon day, the mandala of the new moon day is to be divided by twenty-four, forty-nine parts are to be divided by forty-nine. Here, the sun will be seen on the first new moon day. Similarly, as the full moon days of the sun are named, so are the new moon days.
1. 'Evamityadi' In this way, as the full moon days of the moon are named, so are the new moon days, such as - second, third, twelfth. P. So, on which day of the year will the second new moon be seen in which country? A. In the country where the moon is seen on the first new moon day, the mandala of the new moon day is to be divided by twenty-four, thirty-two parts are to be divided by thirty-two. Here, the moon will be seen on the second new moon day. P. So, on which day of the year will the third new moon be seen in which country? A. In the country where the moon is seen on the second new moon day, the mandala of the new moon day is to be divided by twenty-four, thirty-two parts are to be divided by thirty-two. Here, the moon will be seen on the third new moon day. P. So, on which day of the year will the twelfth new moon be seen in which country? A. In the country where the moon is seen on the new moon day, the mandala of the new moon day is to be divided by twenty-four, two hundred and eighty-eight parts are to be divided by two hundred and eighty-eight. Here, the moon will be seen on the twelfth new moon day.

The 26th part is divided into 70, the remaining 21 parts are the fine parts. 3. Q. P. On the 5th year, on which constellation does the moon fall on the full moon day?

A. On Chitra, on Chitra, 1 Muhurta and 28 parts of the Muhurta, the 26th part is divided into 70, the remaining 30 fine parts. 4. Q. P. On the 5th year, on which constellation does the moon fall on the 12th full moon day?
A. On Uttara, on Ashadha, on Uttara and Ashadha, 26 Muhurtas and 26 parts of the Muhurta, the 26th part is divided into 70, the remaining 44 fine parts. Q. P. On which constellation does the sun fall at that time?
A. On Punarvasu, on Punarvasu, 16 Muhurtas and 8 parts of the Muhurta, the 26th part is divided into 70, the remaining 20 fine parts. 5. Q. P. On the 5th year, on which constellation does the moon fall on the last full moon day?
A. On Uttara, on Ashadha, on Uttara and Ashadha, at the last time. Q. P. On which constellation does the sun fall at that time?
A. On Pushya, on Pushya, 19 Muhurtas and 43 parts of the Muhurta, the 26th part is divided into 70, the remaining 33 fine parts. The conjunction of the moon, sun and constellations on the new moon day 68. 1. Q. P. On the 5th year, on which constellation does the moon fall on the first new moon day?
A. On Aslesha, on Aslesha, 1 Muhurta and 44 parts of the Muhurta, the 26th part is divided into 70, the remaining 26 fine parts. Q. P. On which constellation does the sun fall at that time?
A. On Aslesha, on Aslesha, 1 Muhurta and 44 parts of the Muhurta, the 26th part is divided into 70, the remaining 26 fine parts. 2. Q. P. On the 5th year, on which constellation does the moon fall on the second new moon day?
A. On Uttara, on Falgun, on Uttara and Falgun, 40 Muhurtas and 35 parts of the Muhurta, the 26th part is divided into 70, the remaining 15 fine parts. Q. P. On which constellation does the sun fall at that time?

##  [138]
[Surya Prajnapti Sutra]

**U.**  What is the conjunction of the moon with the asterism Uttara Phalguni in the Uttara Phalguni month?
**A.**  It is the same as the conjunction of the moon with the asterism Uttara Phalguni.

**K.P.**  What is the conjunction of the moon with the asterism Uttara Phalguni on the 5th amavasya of the year?
**U.**  It is 4 muhurtas and 10/60th of a muhurta after the asterism Uttara Phalguni.

**K.P.**  What is the conjunction of the sun with the asterism Uttara Phalguni at that time?
**U.**  It is the same as the conjunction of the moon with the asterism Uttara Phalguni.

**K.P.**  What is the conjunction of the moon with the asterism Uttara Phalguni on the 12th amavasya of the year?
**U.**  It is 4 muhurtas and 10/60th of a muhurta before the asterism Uttara Phalguni.

**K.P.**  What is the conjunction of the sun with the asterism Uttara Phalguni at that time?
**U.**  It is the same as the conjunction of the moon with the asterism Uttara Phalguni.

**K.P.**  What is the conjunction of the moon with the asterism Uttara Phalguni on the last amavasya of the year?
**U.**  It is 22 muhurtas and 42/60th of a muhurta after the asterism Punarvasu.

**K.P.**  What is the conjunction of the sun with the asterism Uttara Phalguni at that time?
**U.**  It is the same as the conjunction of the moon with the asterism Uttara Phalguni.

**K.P.**  What is the time difference between the conjunction of the moon and the sun with the asterisms?
**U.**  The time difference between the conjunction of the moon and the sun with the asterisms is 69.

**K.P.**  If the conjunction of the moon with an asterism is observed in one place, what is the time difference for the conjunction of the moon with the same asterism in another place?
**U.**  If the conjunction of the moon with an asterism is observed in one place, the time difference for the conjunction of the moon with the same asterism in another place is 18 muhurtas and 24/60th of a muhurta.

**K.P.**  If the conjunction of the moon with an asterism is observed in one place, what is the time difference for the conjunction of the moon with the same asterism in another place?
**U.**  If the conjunction of the moon with an asterism is observed in one place, the time difference for the conjunction of the moon with the same asterism in another place is 16 muhurtas and 44/60th of a muhurta.

**K.P.**  If the conjunction of the moon with an asterism is observed in one place, what is the time difference for the conjunction of the moon with the same asterism in another place?
**U.**  If the conjunction of the moon with an asterism is observed in one place, the time difference for the conjunction of the moon with the same asterism in another place is 4000 muhurtas and 9 muhurtas.

**K.P.**  If the conjunction of the moon with an asterism is observed in one place, what is the time difference for the conjunction of the moon with the same asterism in another place?
**U.**  If the conjunction of the moon with an asterism is observed in one place, the time difference for the conjunction of the moon with the same asterism in another place is 1009 muhurtas and 8 muhurtas.

10th Prabhrita - Twenty-second Prabhrita

2. a. By which constellation the sun is conjoined, in that region he takes up the three sets of thirty-six lunar days. Then again, he is conjoined by another similar constellation in that region.

b. By which constellation the sun is conjoined, in that region he takes up the thirty-seven sets of lunar days. Then again, he is conjoined by another similar constellation in that region.

c. By which constellation the sun is conjoined, in that region he takes up the eighteen sets of thirty-one lunar days. Then again, he is conjoined by the same constellation in that region.

d. By which constellation the sun is conjoined, in that region he takes up the thirty-six sets of sixty lunar days. Then again, he is conjoined by the same constellation in that region.

70. The attainment of the course of the moon, sun, planets, and constellations. When this moon attains the course, then the other moons also attain the course. When the other moons attain the course, then this moon also attains the course. When this sun attains the course, then the other suns also attain the course. When the other suns attain the course, then this sun also attains the course. Similarly for the planets and constellations.

The conjunction of the moon, sun, planets, and constellations.
When this moon is conjoined in the conjunction, then the other moons also are conjoined in the conjunction. When the other moons are conjoined in the conjunction, then this moon also is conjoined in the conjunction. Similarly for the sun, planets, and constellations. Some moons are conjoined in the conjunctions, some suns are conjoined in the conjunctions, some planets are conjoined in the conjunctions, some constellations are conjoined in the conjunctions, both the moons are conjoined in the conjunctions,

## Eleventh Prabhruta

**Five years, the beginning of the Paryushana period, and the time of the conjunction of the moon, sun, and constellations - 71. K.1. P. How are these years, etc.?**

**A. It is said,**

**U. There are five years designated here, as follows:**

1. Canda
2. Canda
3. Abhivaddiya
4. Canda
5. Abhivaddiya

**The first Canda year - K.1. P. What is the beginning of the first Canda year in these five years?**

**A. It is said,**

**U. The beginning of the first Canda year is at the Paryushana of the fifth Abhivaddiya year, and the time is after that.**

**G. P. What is the Paryushana?**

**A. It is said,**

**U. The Paryushana of the first Canda year is at the beginning of the second Canda year, and the time is after that.**

**Gh. P. What constellation is the moon in at that time?**

**U. It is in Uttara Ashadha, 26 Muhurtas of Uttara Ashadha, 62 parts of a Muhurta, 77 parts of a part of a Muhurta, and 44 parts of a part of a part of a Muhurta remaining.**

**P. What constellation is the sun in at that time?**

**U. It is in Punarvasu, 16 Muhurtas of Punarvasu, 8 parts of a Muhurta, 72 parts of a part of a Muhurta, and 20 parts of a part of a part of a Muhurta remaining.**

**The second Canda year - K.2. P. What is the beginning of the second Canda year in these five years?**

**A. It is said,**

**U. The beginning of the second Canda year is at the Paryushana of the first Canda year, and the time is after that.**

**Kh. P. What is the Paryushana?**

**A. It is said,**

U. So, what is the beginning of the *Abhivaddhiya* year?  
P.  At the end of the *Dvoccha* lunar year, the next moment is the beginning of the *Abhivaddhiya* year.
U.  At that time, what constellation is the moon in?
P.  In the *Purva Ashadha*, seven *muhurtas* of the *Purva Ashadha*, 26 parts of the *muhurta*, 70 parts of the *bhaga*, 39 parts of the *churniya* are remaining.
U.  At that time, what constellation is the sun in?
P.  In the *Punarvasu*, 42 *muhurtas* of the *Punarvasu*, 35 parts of the *muhurta*, 60 parts of the *bhaga*, 7 parts of the *churniya* are remaining.
K.  What is the beginning of the third *Abhivaddhiya* year?
P.  So, what is the beginning of the third *Abhivaddhiya* year in the five years?
U.  At the end of the *Dvoccha* lunar year, the next moment is the beginning of the third *Abhivaddhiya* year.
K.  What is the beginning of the third *Abhivaddhiya* year?
U.  At the beginning of the fourth lunar year, the next moment is the end of the third *Abhivaddhiya* year.
P.  At that time, what constellation is the moon in?
U.  In the *Uttara Ashadha*, 13 *muhurtas* of the *Uttara Ashadha*, 26 parts of the *muhurta*, 70 parts of the *bhaga*, 27 parts of the *churniya* are remaining.
U.  At that time, what constellation is the sun in?
P.  In the *Punarvasu*, 2 *muhurtas* of the *Punarvasu*, 56 parts of the *muhurta*, 60 parts of the *bhaga*, 60 parts of the *churniya* are remaining.
K.  What is the beginning of the fourth lunar year?
P.  So, what is the beginning of the fourth lunar year in the five years?
U.  At the end of the third *Abhivaddhiya* year, the next moment is the beginning of the fourth lunar year.
K.  What is the beginning of the fourth lunar year?
U.  At the beginning of the last *Abhivaddhiya* year, the next moment is the end of the fourth lunar year.
P.  At that time, what constellation is the moon in?

## Eleventh Prabhruta

[143]

**Q:** On what day and time does the eleventh Prabhruta begin?

**A:** It begins on the Uttara Ashadha, forty-four Muhurtas after the beginning of Uttara Ashadha. Forty-four Muhurtas are equal to sixty-four parts of a Muhurta, and sixty-four parts are equal to seventy-two parts of a Muhurta. The remaining parts are forty-four.

**Q:** At that time, in which Nakshatra is the Sun?

**A:** At that time, the Sun is in Punarvasu. The Sun is twenty-nine Muhurtas and twenty-one parts of a Muhurta into Punarvasu. Twenty-one parts of a Muhurta are equal to seventy-two parts of a Muhurta. The remaining parts are fifty-three.

**Q:** What is the beginning of the fifth Abhivaddhiya year?

**A:** Please tell me.

**A:** The beginning of the fifth Abhivaddhiya year is the end of the fourth Chandra year.

**Q:** When is the end of the fourth Chandra year?

**A:** Please tell me.

**A:** The end of the fourth Chandra year is the beginning of the first year.

**Q:** At that time, in which Nakshatra is the Moon?

**A:** At that time, the Moon is in Uttara Ashadha, at the end of Uttara Ashadha.

**Q:** At that time, in which Nakshatra is the Sun?

**A:** At that time, the Sun is in Pushya. The Sun is twenty-one Muhurtas and forty-three parts of a Muhurta into Pushya. Forty-three parts of a Muhurta are equal to seventy-two parts of a Muhurta. The remaining parts are thirty-three.

## Twelfth Prabhrit

**Five Years, Months and Muhurta Measurement** - 72. K.1. P. How many years are there? Tell me.
**A.** There are five years mentioned here, namely: 1. Nakshatra, 2. Chandra, 3. Udu, 4. Aicha, 5. Abhivaddhia. 

**First Nakshatra Year** - K. P. How many Muhurtas are there in the first Nakshatra year, in the Nakshatra month, with 30 Muhurtas per day? Tell me.
**A.** There are 27 Raindhiyas and 21/60th of a Raindhiya, tell me. G. P. How many Muhurtas are there? Tell me.
**A.** There are 821 Muhurtas and 27/60th of a Muhurta, tell me. Gh. P. This is half of the 12-Nakshatra year, how many Raindhiyas are there? Tell me.
**A.** There are 327 Raindhiyas and 51/60th of a Raindhiya, tell me. Ng. P. How many Muhurtas are there? Tell me.
**A.** There are 9832 Muhurtas and 56/60th of a Muhurta, tell me.

**Second Chandra Year** - 2. K. P. How many Raindhiyas are there in the second Chandra year, in the Chandra month, with 30 Muhurtas per day? Tell me.
**A.** There are 39 Raindhiyas and 32/60th of a Raindhiya, tell me.

## Twelfth Prabhrit

**1. **
**Q.** How many Muhurta-Ggas are there in a Chandrasamvatsara?
**A.** There are 850 Muhurtas and 36 parts of a Muhurta in a Chandrasamvatsara.

**2.**
**Q.** How many Raindhiya-Ggas are there in half of a Chandrasamvatsara (12 Muhurta-Kadas)?
**A.** There are 372 Raindhiyas and 12 parts of a Raindhiya in half of a Chandrasamvatsara.

**3.**
**Q.** How many Muhurta-Ggas are there in half of a Chandrasamvatsara (12 Muhurta-Kadas)?
**A.** There are 10,069 Muhurtas and 25 parts of a Muhurta in half of a Chandrasamvatsara.

**Second Udusamvatsara (3)**

**1.**
**Q.** If there are 15 years and the Udusamvatsara has 30 Muhurtas in its Udumas, how many Raindhiya-Ggas are there in 30 Muhurtas?
**A.** There are 30 Raindhiyas in 30 Muhurtas.

**2.**
**Q.** How many Muhurta-Ggas are there in 30 Muhurtas?
**A.** There are 900 Muhurta-Ggas in 30 Muhurtas.

**3.**
**Q.** How many Raindhiya-Ggas are there in half of an Udusamvatsara (12 Muhurta-Kadas)?
**A.** There are 306 Raindhiyas in half of an Udusamvatsara.

**4.**
**Q.** How many Muhurta-Ggas are there in half of an Udusamvatsara (12 Muhurta-Kadas)?
**A.** There are 10,080 Muhurta-Ggas in half of an Udusamvatsara.

**Third Aicchasamvatsara (4)**

**1.**
**Q.** If there are 15 years and the Aicchasamvatsara has 30 Muhurtas in its Aicchamas, how many Raindhiya-Ggas are there in 30 Muhurtas?
**A.** There are 30 Raindhiyas and half a part of a Raindhiya in 30 Muhurtas.

**2.**
**Q.** How many Muhurta-Ggas are there in 30 Muhurtas?
**A.** There are 915 Muhurta-Ggas in 30 Muhurtas.

**3.**
**Q.** How many Raindhiya-Ggas are there in half of an Aicchasamvatsara (12 Muhurta-Kadas)?
**A.** There are 306 Raindhiyas in half of an Aicchasamvatsara.

**4.**
**Q.** How many Muhurta-Ggas are there in half of an Aicchasamvatsara (12 Muhurta-Kadas)?
**A.** There are 10,090 Muhurta-Ggas in half of an Aicchasamvatsara.

##  [Surya Prajnapti Sutra]

**146]**

**5. a.  ** If a *Abhivaddiya* year is five years, then how many *Raindhiya* units are there in the fifth *Abhivaddiya* year? 
**Answer:** There are thirty-nine *Raindhiya* units and thirty-three *Muhurta* units, seventeen sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit.

**b. ** How many *Muhurta* units are there in the fifth *Abhivaddiya* year?
**Answer:** There are nine hundred and ninety-seven *Muhurta* units, seventeen sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit.

**c. ** If half of a *Dvaadasa Khutta Kada* is an *Abhivaddiya* year, then how many *Raindhiya* units are there in it?
**Answer:** There are three hundred and thirty-three *Raindhiya* units and thirty-one *Muhurta* units, eighteen sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit.

**d. ** How many *Muhurta* units are there in half of a *Dvaadasa Khutta Kada*?
**Answer:** There are eleven thousand and fifty-five *Muhurta* units, eighteen sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit.

**73. a. ** How many *Raindhiya* units are there in nine *Yuga*s?
**Answer:** There are seventeen thousand and eighty-nine *Raindhiya* units, nineteen *Muhurta* units, forty-seven sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit, and seventy-six sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit, which is equal to one and sixteen sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit.

**b. ** How many *Muhurta* units are there in nine *Yuga*s?
**Answer:** There are seventy-nine thousand and forty-nine *Muhurta* units, forty-seven sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit, and seventy-six sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit, which is equal to one and sixteen sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit.

**c. ** How many *Raindhiya* units are there in a *Jagapatti*?
**Answer:** There are thirty-eight *Raindhiya* units, ten *Muhurta* units, four sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit, and seventy-six sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit, which is equal to one and sixteen sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit.

**d. ** How many *Muhurta* units are there in a *Jagapatti*?
**Answer:** There are eleven thousand and forty-five *Muhurta* units, four sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit, and seventy-six sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit, which is equal to one and sixteen sixtyths of a *Muhurta* unit.

**e. ** How many *Raindhiya* units are there in a *Yuga*?
**Answer:** There are eighteen thousand and thirty-three *Raindhiya* units.

## Twelfth Prabhrit

**C. Q. How many Muhurtas are there in a year?**
**A. There are 44,000 Muhurtas, 900 Muhurtas, and some Muhurtas, in a year.**

**The completion of the Parambha-Pajjavasa period of five years**
**147**

**C. Q. How many 60th parts of a Muhurta are there in a year?**
**A. There are 34,000, 28, and 60th parts of a Muhurta in a year.**

**74. 1. K. Q. How many solar and lunar years are there in a Samadi Samapajjavasi?**
**A. There are 60 solar months and 62 lunar months.**

**These are half of 12 Khuttakadas, 12 times 30 solar years, and 31 lunar years.**
**Therefore, there are 30 solar years and 31 lunar years in a Samadi Samapajjavasi.**

**Kh. Q. How many solar, Udu, lunar, and Nakshatra years are there in a Samadi Samapajjavasi?**
**A. There are 60 solar months, 61 Udu months, 62 lunar months, and 70 Nakshatra months.**

**These are half of 12 Khuttakadas, 12 times 60 solar years, 61 Udu years, 62 lunar years, and 70 Nakshatra years.**
**Therefore, there are 60 solar years, 61 Udu years, 62 lunar years, and 70 Nakshatra years in a Samadi Samapajjavasi.**

**G. Q. How many Abhivaddiya solar, Udu, lunar, and Nakshatra years are there in a Samadi Samapajjavasi?**
**A. There are 77 months, 7 days, 11 Muhurtas, 20 60th parts of a Muhurta in an Abhivaddiya month, 60 solar months, 61 Udu months, 62 lunar months, and 70 Nakshatra months.**

**These are half of 56 Khuttakadas, 12 times 744 Abhivaddiya years, 780 solar years, 791 Udu years, 876 lunar years, and 1088 Nakshatra years.**
**Therefore, there are 744 Abhivaddiya years, 780 solar years, 791 Udu years, 876 lunar years, and 1088 Nakshatra years in a Samadi Samapajjavasi.**

## English Translation:

**148]**
**1.**  "What is the duration of a *rainditya*?"
**2.**  "It is said that in a lunar year, three *chaupaṇṇa* *rainditya*s, twelve and sixty-four parts of a *rainditya*, constitute a *rainditya*."
**3.**  "It is said that in a lunar year, three *chaupaṇṇa* *rainditya*s, five *muhūrta*s, fifty and sixty-four parts of a *muhūrta*, constitute a *rainditya*."

**75.**
**[Sūryaprajñaptisūtra]**
**1.**  "There are six seasons, namely: 1. *Pāusa*, 2. *Varisārātta*, 3. *Sarata*, 4. *Hemānta*, 5. *Vasānta*, 6. *Gimha*."
**2.**  "All these six seasons, two months each, are calculated by the *chaupaṇṇa* *chaupaṇṇa* *āyāṇa* and are said to be sixty-one *rainditya*s in a *rainditya*."

**3.**  "There are six *avam* *aitiratta*s, namely: 1. *Taiya* *pavva*, 2. *Sattama* *pavva*, 3. *Ekkārasa* *pavva*, 4. *Paṇṇarasa* *pavva*, 5. *Egūṇavīsai* *pavva*, 6. *Tevisai* *pavva*."

**4.**  "There are six *atiratta*s, namely: 1. *Chauttha* *pavva*, 2. *Aṭṭhama* *pavva*, 3. *Bārasa* *pavva*, 4. *Solasama* *pavva*, 5. *Vīsai* *pavva*, 6. *Chauvīsai* *pavva*."

**5.**  **Gāhā**
"Six are *aitiratta*s, they are the days of humans.
Six are *avam* *aitiratta*s, they are the days of the moon."

**76.**
**1.**  "There are five *vāsikki*s and five *hemānta* *auṭṭi*s."
**2.**  "In a period of five years, on which *nakkhatta* does the first *vāsikki* *auṭṭi* occur?"
**3.**  "It occurs on the *nakkhatta* *Abhijinā* *Abhijinā*."
**4.**  "On which *nakkhatta* does the sun occur at that time?"
**5.**  "It occurs on the *nakkhatta* *Pūsa*, nineteen *muhūrta*s and forty-two parts of a *muhūrta*, two parts of a *muhūrta*, seven parts of a *cheṭṭā*, thirty-three parts of a *cuṇṇiya*."
**6.**  "In a period of five years, on which *nakkhatta* does the second *vāsikki* *auṭṭi* occur?"

**Notes:**

* **rainditya:** A unit of time used in Jain cosmology.
* **chaupaṇṇa:** A unit of time equal to 72 *muhūrta*s.
* **muhūrta:** A unit of time equal to 48 minutes.
* **āyāṇa:** A unit of time equal to 30 days.
* **avam:** A lunar day that is shorter than a solar day.
* **aitiratta:** A lunar day that is longer than a solar day.
* **pavva:** A lunar day.
* **vāsikki:** A type of lunar eclipse.
* **auṭṭi:** A type of lunar eclipse.
* **nakkhatta:** A lunar mansion.
* **cheṭṭā:** A unit of time equal to 1/12 of a *muhūrta*.
* **cuṇṇiya:** A unit of time equal to 1/144 of a *muhūrta*.

## Twelfth Prabhrit

**1.** **Q.** In what constellation does the moon rise at the beginning of the first Hemanti-Avatti of the five-year cycle?
**A.** In Hathi, the fifth muhurta of Hathi, with fifty bavatthi-bhagas of the muhurta, and seventy-seven chunniya-bhagas remaining after dividing the bavatthi-bhagas by seventy-two.
**Q.** In what constellation does the sun rise at that time?
**A.** In Uttara Ashadha, at the end of Uttara Ashadha.

**2.** **Q.** In what constellation does the moon rise at the beginning of the second Hemanti-Avatti of the five-year cycle?
**A.** In Satabhisha, the second muhurta of Satabhisha, with twenty-eight bavatthi-bhagas of the muhurta, and forty-three chunniya-bhagas remaining after dividing the bavatthi-bhagas by seventy-two.
**Q.** In what constellation does the sun rise at that time?
**A.** In Uttara Ashadha, at the end of Uttara Ashadha.

**3.** **Q.** In what constellation does the moon rise at the beginning of the first Vasikkin of the five-year cycle?
**A.** In Visakha, the thirteenth muhurta of Visakha, with forty-four bavatthi-bhagas of the muhurta, and forty-four chunniya-bhagas remaining after dividing the bavatthi-bhagas by seventy-two.
**Q.** In what constellation does the sun rise at that time?
**A.** In Pushya, at the beginning of Pushya.

**4.** **Q.** In what constellation does the moon rise at the beginning of the fourth Vasikkin of the five-year cycle?
**A.** In Revati, the nineteenth muhurta of Revati, with thirty-two bavatthi-bhagas of the muhurta, and thirty-six chunniya-bhagas remaining after dividing the bavatthi-bhagas by seventy-two.
**Q.** In what constellation does the sun rise at that time?
**A.** In Pushya, at the beginning of Pushya.

**5.** **Q.** In what constellation does the moon rise at the beginning of the fifth Vasikkin of the five-year cycle?
**A.** In Purva Phalguni, the twelfth muhurta of Purva Phalguni, with forty-seven bavatthi-bhagas of the muhurta, and thirteen chunniya-bhagas remaining after dividing the bavatthi-bhagas by seventy-two.
**Q.** In what constellation does the sun rise at that time?
**A.** In Pushya, at the beginning of Pushya.

**6.** **Q.** In what constellation does the moon rise at the beginning of the first Avatti of the five-year cycle?
**A.** In Santhana, the eleventh muhurta of Santhana, with thirty-nine bavatthi-bhagas of the muhurta, and seventy-seven chunniya-bhagas remaining after dividing the bavatthi-bhagas by seventy-two.
**Q.** In what constellation does the sun rise at that time?
**A.** In Pushya, at the beginning of Pushya.

## 150]
[Surya Prajnapti Sutra]
3. a. P. What is the 5th Hemanti Utt (lunar eclipse) in a cycle of 5 years, on which Nakshatra (constellation) does the Moon fall?
U. On Pushya, 19 Muhurtas (time units) of Pushya, 43 Bavatthi Bhaga (sub-units of Muhurta), 72 Chettha (sub-units of Bavatthi Bhaga), 33 Chunniya Bhaga (sub-units of Chettha) remaining.
b. P. On which Nakshatra does the Sun fall at that time?
U. On Uttara Ashadha, at the end of Uttara Ashadha.
4. a. P. What is the 4th Hemanti Utt in a cycle of 5 years, on which Nakshatra does the Moon fall?
U. On Mula, 6 Muhurtas of Mula, 48 Bavatthi Bhaga, 70 Chettha, 20 Chunniya Bhaga remaining.
b. P. On which Nakshatra does the Sun fall at that time?
U. On Uttara Ashadha, at the end of Uttara Ashadha.
5. a. P. What is the 5th Hemanti Utt in a cycle of 5 years, on which Nakshatra does the Moon fall?
U. On Krittika, 18 Muhurtas of Krittika, 36 Bavatthi Bhaga, 70 Chettha, 0 Chunniya Bhaga remaining.
b. P. On which Nakshatra does the Sun fall at that time?
U. On Uttara Ashadha, at the end of Uttara Ashadha.
The Moon's conjunction with the Sun, and the conjunction's duration, 78.
There are 10 types of conjunctions, as follows:
1. Vasbhanu Joge, 2. Venuyanu Joge, 3. Manche Joge, 4. Manchai Manche Joge, 5. Chhatte Joge, 6. Chhattai Chhatte Joge, 7. Jaanaddhe Joge, 8. Ghansammadde Joge, 9. Pinie Joge, 10. Mandukaputte Joge.
1. P. What is the Chhattai Chhatte Joge (conjunction) of the Moon in a cycle of 5 years, in which country does it occur?
U. In Jambudvipa, in the Paiin-Padini Ayyaya, Udin-Dahin Ayyaya, the Jeeva Mandala (sphere of life) is divided into 24 parts, in the southern-eastern quadrant, 27 parts are to be counted, 28 parts are to be counted, 18 parts are to be counted, in these 3 parts, 2 Kala (sub-units of parts), the southern-eastern quadrant is incomplete, here the Chhattai Chhatte Joge of the Moon occurs.
The Moon rises, is in the middle of the Nakshatra, and sets.
2. P. On which Nakshatra does the Moon fall at that time?
U. On Chitra, at the end of Chitra.

## Thirteenth Praabhrut

**B.**
**79. Q.** How is the moon's increase and decrease? Please explain.
**A.**  It is 75 muhurtas and 30 bavatthi bhagas of a muhurta. 
**Q.** How is the moon's increase and decrease in the dark fortnight?
**A.** In the dark fortnight, the moon increases for 412 muhurtas and 36 bavatthi bhagas of a muhurta. For example, in the first day, the first part increases, in the second day, the second part increases, and so on, until the 15th day, the 15th part increases. At the end, the moon becomes full. In the remaining time, the moon becomes both full and waning. This is called Amavasya. 
Similarly, in the first fortnight, on Amavasya, the dark fortnight begins. In the dark fortnight, the moon increases for 412 muhurtas and 36 bavatthi bhagas of a muhurta. For example, in the first day, the first part increases, in the second day, the second part increases, and so on, until the 15th day, the 15th part increases. At the end, the moon becomes waning. In the remaining time, the moon becomes both full and waning. This is called Purnima. 
Similarly, in the second fortnight, it is Purnima.

**80. Q.** How many Purnimas and Amavasyas are there in one Yuga?
**A.** There are 48 Purnimas and 48 Amavasyas. There are 48 Kasina ragas, 48 Kasina viragas, 24 fortnights, and 24 Kasina raga-viraga fortnights. In 5 years, there are 24 such fortnights.

[ Surya Prajnapti Sutra ]
It is said that there are countless days, passions, and dispassions in this world.  On the new moon, there are 480 muhurtas and 36 parts of a muhurta.  On the full moon, there are 480 muhurtas and 36 parts of a muhurta.  On the new moon, there are 85 muhurtas and 30 parts of a muhurta.  On the full moon, there are 85 muhurtas and 30 parts of a muhurta.  This is the case in a lunar month.
This is the case in all the yugas.  The moon travels 81 mandalas in half a lunar month.  Q. How many mandalas does the moon travel in half a lunar month?  A. The moon travels 14 and 1/24th mandalas in half a lunar month.  Q. How many mandalas does the moon travel in half a solar month?  A. The moon travels 16 mandalas in half a solar month.  The moon travels 16 mandalas, and there are two exceptional movements of the moon.  Q. What are the two exceptional movements of the moon?  A. The two exceptional movements of the moon are: 1. When the moon is leaving the new moon, 2. When the moon is entering the full moon.  These are the two exceptional movements of the moon.  In the first lunar month,
When the moon enters the southern part of the sky in the first lunar month, it travels 7 and 1/2 mandalas.

## Thirteenth Prabhruta

[153]

When the Moon enters the right side, it moves through four (quarters).  P. Which are those four quarters through which the Moon moves when it enters the right side in seven half-mandalas?  U. These are the seven half-mandalas through which the Moon moves when it enters the right side:

1. Second half-mandala
2. Fourth half-mandala
3. Sixth half-mandala
4. Eighth half-mandala
5. Tenth half-mandala
6. Twelfth half-mandala
7. Fourteenth half-mandala

These are the seven half-mandalas through which the Moon moves when it enters the right side.  When the Moon enters the north side in the first Ayan, it moves through six half-mandalas and thirteen and seventy-six parts of a half-mandala.  When the Moon enters the north side, it moves through four (quarters).  P. Which are those four quarters through which the Moon moves when it enters the north side in six half-mandalas and thirteen and seventy-six parts of a half-mandala?  U. These are the six half-mandalas and thirteen and seventy-six parts of a half-mandala through which the Moon moves when it enters the north side:

1. Third half-mandala
2. Fifth half-mandala
3. Seventh half-mandala
4. Ninth half-mandala
5. Eleventh half-mandala
6. Thirteenth half-mandala and thirteen and seventy-six parts of the fifteenth mandala.

These are the six half-mandalas and thirteen and seventy-six parts of a half-mandala through which the Moon moves when it enters the north side.  Thus, the first Chandrayan is completed.

In the second Chandrayan...  Neither in the half-month of the Nakshatra nor in the half-month of the Moon,

Neither in the half-month of the Moon nor in the half-month of the Nakshatra,

[154]
[Surya Prajnapti Sutra]
Q. What is the path of the moon in half a lunar month?
A. It travels half a circle, 77 parts of half a circle, 31 parts and 9 parts. When the moon exits from the last part of the Uttarayana, it travels 7 parts and 4 parts of the other's circle, 7 parts and 13 parts of its own circle. When the moon exits from the last part of the Dakshinayana, it travels 6 parts and 4 parts of the other's circle, 6 parts and 13 parts of its own circle. The remaining 2 parts and 13 parts of the moon travel in an unusual way, self-illuminated.
Q. How do these 2 parts and 13 parts of the moon travel in an unusual way, self-illuminated?
A. These 2 parts and 13 parts of the moon travel in an unusual way, self-illuminated, in two ways: 1. Within the entire circle, 2. Outside the entire circle. These 2 parts and 13 parts of the moon travel in an unusual way, self-illuminated, in these two ways.
This completes the explanation of the Uttarayana and Dakshinayana of the moon.
In a lunar month, there is no solar month,
In a solar month, there is no lunar month.
Q. What is the path of the moon in half a lunar month?
A. It travels two half circles, 8 parts and 77 parts of half a circle, 77 parts and 31 parts and 18 parts. When the moon enters from the last part of the Dakshinayana, it travels 11 parts and 77 parts of its own circle, and 13 parts and 77 parts of the other's circle.

[The Thirteenth Prabhrta]

The moon traverses thirteen and sixty-seven parts of its own and the other's course. This makes up the complete half-circle of the outer (eastern) side. When the moon enters the eastern part, it traverses forty-eight and sixty-seven parts of the outer eastern half-circle, thirteen and sixty-seven parts of the other's course, and thirteen and sixty-seven parts of its own course. This completes the outer eastern half-circle. 

When the moon enters the western part, it traverses eighty-seven and sixty-seven parts of the fourth western half-circle, and subtracting sixty-seven parts, it traverses eighteen parts of its own and the other's course. This completes the fourth western half-circle.

Thus, the moon in one month traverses thirteen and forty-four parts of the other's course, thirteen and thirteen parts of its own course, two and forty-one parts, eighty-seven and sixty-seven parts, subtracting sixty-seven parts, it traverses eighteen parts of its own and the other's course. The remaining two and thirteen parts, which the moon traverses by itself without any association, constitute its wandering course.

This is the moon, the moon, the auspicious, the moon, the moon.

## Fourteenth Prabhruta

**The Many Causes of Darkness and Sin**

**A.**

1. **Question:** What are the many causes of sin?
**Answer:** The many causes of sin are on the side of sin.
2. **Question:** How are the many causes of sin on the side of sin?
**Answer:** The many causes of sin are on the side of darkness.
3. **Question:** How are the many causes of sin on the side of darkness?
**Answer:** When the moon is waning, there are 48 muhutas and 64 parts of a muhuta, and the moon is waning in those 64 parts. For example, the first part is waning in the first part, the second part is waning in the second part, and so on until the 15th part is waning in the 15th part. Thus, the many causes of sin are on the side of darkness.
4. **Question:** How many are the many causes of sin?
**Answer:** They are countless.

**B.**

1. **Question:** What are the many causes of darkness?
**Answer:** The many causes of darkness are on the side of darkness.
2. **Question:** How are the many causes of darkness on the side of darkness?
**Answer:** The many causes of darkness are on the side of sin.
3. **Question:** How are the many causes of darkness on the side of sin?
**Answer:** When the moon is waning, there are 48 muhutas and 64 parts of a muhuta, and the moon is waning in those 64 parts. For example, the first part is waning in the first part, the second part is waning in the second part, and so on until the 15th part is waning in the 15th part. Thus, the many causes of darkness are on the side of sin.
4. **Question:** How many are the many causes of darkness?
**Answer:** They are countless.

**Note:** The meaning of Sutra 79 in the Surya Prajnapti Prabhruta 13 and Sutra 82 in the Surya Prajnapti Prabhruta 14 is the same. The only difference is that Sutra 79 speaks of the "decrease and increase of the moon," while Sutra 82 speaks of the "increase of moonlight and darkness." However, the decrease and increase of the moon leads to the increase of moonlight and darkness.

## Fifteenth Praabhrut

**The Relative Speed of the Moon, Sun, Planets, Constellations, and Stars**

**Q:** How do these (Moon, Sun, Planets, Constellations, and Stars) move in relation to each other?

**A:** The Moon moves faster than the Sun, the Sun faster than the Planets, the Planets faster than the Constellations, and the Constellations faster than the Stars. The Moon is the slowest of all, and the Stars are the fastest.

**Q:** How many parts of its own circle does the Moon traverse in a Muhurta (48 minutes)?

**A:** The Moon traverses 77/64 parts of its own circle in a Muhurta. Its circle is 100,000 yojanas in circumference.

**Q:** How many parts of its own circle does the Sun traverse in a Muhurta?

**A:** The Sun traverses 18/32 parts of its own circle in a Muhurta. Its circle is 100,000 yojanas in circumference.

**Q:** Which of these (Moon, Sun, Planets, Constellations, and Stars) moves faster or slower than the others?

**A:** The Moon moves faster than the Sun, the Sun faster than the Planets, the Planets faster than the Constellations, and the Constellations faster than the Stars. The Moon is the slowest of all, and the Stars are the fastest.

**Note:** The text does not mention the speed of the Planets. The commentator explains that the Planets have irregular and unpredictable movements, so their speed cannot be calculated in the same way as the Moon, Sun, Constellations, and Stars. 

**Commentary:**

The Planets move in a curved and irregular manner, so their speed cannot be calculated in the same way as the Moon, Sun, Constellations, and Stars. The text states that the Moon moves faster than the Sun, the Sun faster than the Planets, and so on. The Planets are all slower than the Moon.

**Further Explanation:**

* The Moon traverses 77/64 parts of its own circle in a Muhurta.
* The Sun traverses 18/32 parts of its own circle in a Muhurta.
* The Planets have irregular and unpredictable movements, so their speed cannot be calculated in the same way as the Moon, Sun, Constellations, and Stars.
* The Constellations are slower than the Planets.
* The Stars are the fastest of all.

**3. Q. How many parts of a *nakṣatra* does the moon traverse in a *muhūrta*?**

**A.** The moon traverses 18 and 1/3 parts of the *nakṣatra* in a *muhūrta*. The moon traverses 19 parts of the *maṇḍala* in 100,000 *maṇḍalas*.

**Specific Differences in the Motion of the Sun, Moon, and *Nakṣatras***

**84**

**(Sun-Moon-Nakṣatra)**

**1. Q. What is the difference in the motion of the moon and the sun when they are in conjunction?**

**A.** The difference is 22 parts.

**2. Q. What is the difference in the motion of the moon and the *nakṣatra* when they are in conjunction?**

**A.** The difference is 77 parts.

**3. Q. What is the difference in the motion of the sun and the *nakṣatra* when they are in conjunction?**

**A.** The difference is 5 parts.

**Conjunction of the Moon and *Nakṣatras***

When the moon is in conjunction with a *nakṣatra* in the eastern part of the sky, it will be in conjunction with the *nakṣatra* for 9 *muhūrtas* and 77 parts of a *muhūrta*. The conjunction will then be in the *anupariyatṭa* state. When the conjunction is in the *anupariyatṭa* state, it will be in the *vippajahaḍa* state until it becomes a *vigayajogī*.

When the moon is in conjunction with a *nakṣatra* in the eastern part of the sky, it will be in conjunction with the *nakṣatra* for 30 *muhūrtas*. The conjunction will then be in the *anupariyatṭa* state. When the conjunction is in the *anupariyatṭa* state, it will be in the *vippajahaḍa* state until it becomes a *vigayajogī*.

This should be applied to the 15th, 30th, and 45th *muhūrtas*. It should be said that the moon is in conjunction with the *nakṣatra* until the *Uttaraṣāḍhā* *nakṣatra*.

**Conjunction of the Moon and Planets**

**84. Q. When the moon is in conjunction with a planet in the eastern part of the sky, what is the duration of the conjunction?**

**A.** When the moon is in conjunction with a planet in the eastern part of the sky, the conjunction will be in the *anupariyatṭa* state. When the conjunction is in the *anupariyatṭa* state, it will be in the *vippajahaḍa* state until it becomes a *vigayajogī*.

## Fifteenth Praabhrut

[159]

In the eastern part, when the sun sets, it joins with the moon for four days and six muhurtas. When it joins, it gradually moves away from the moon. When it moves away, it leaves the moon. The moon becomes free from the sun's influence.

Thus, in six days and twenty-one muhurtas, in thirteen days and twelve muhurtas, and in twenty days and three muhurtas, all should be said as follows:

When the sun sets in the Uttaraashaadha Nakshatra, it sets in the eastern part. When it sets in the eastern part, it joins with the moon for twenty days and three muhurtas. When it joins, it gradually moves away from the moon. When it moves away, it leaves the moon. The moon becomes free from the sun's influence. The sun's influence on the moon is the time of its departure.

When the sun sets in the moon's setting, it sets in the eastern part. When it sets in the eastern part, it joins with the moon. When it joins, it gradually moves away from the moon. When it moves away, it leaves the moon. The moon becomes free from the sun's influence.

**A - The Moon's, Sun's, and Nakshatra's Movement in a Nakshatra Month**

85.

**The number of circles of the moon, sun, and nakshatra in five nakshatra months**

1. Q. How many circles does the moon make in a nakshatra month?
A. It makes thirteen circles and sixty-seven parts of a circle.

2. Q. How many circles does the sun make in a nakshatra month?
A. It makes thirteen circles and forty-four parts of a circle.

3. Q. How many circles does the nakshatra make in a nakshatra month?
A. It makes thirteen circles and forty-five parts of a circle.

**B - The Moon's, Sun's, and Nakshatra's Movement in a Chandra Month**

1. Q. How many circles does the moon make in a chandra month?
A. It makes fourteen and one-fourth circles and one part of a circle.

2. Q. How many circles does the sun make in a chandra month?
A. It makes thirteen and one-fourth circles and one part of a circle.

3. Q. How many circles does the nakshatra make in a chandra month?
A. It makes fifteen and one-fourth circles and six parts of a circle.

**C - The Moon's, Sun's, and Nakshatra's Movement in an Udu Month**

1. Q. How many circles does the moon make in an udu month?
A. It makes fourteen circles and thirty-one parts of a circle.

2. Q. How many circles does the sun make in an udu month?

##  [Surya Prajnapti Sutra]

**160]**

**Q. How many mandalas does the moon traverse in a *panna-rasa* month?**
**A.** It traverses fifteen mandalas, and three and a half *bhagas* of a mandala.

**Q. How many mandalas does the sun traverse in a *panna-rasa* month?**
**A.** It traverses fifteen mandalas, and five and thirty-two hundredths *bhagas* of a mandala.

**Q. How many mandalas does the *nakshatra* traverse in a *panna-rasa* month?**
**A.** It traverses fifteen mandalas, and five and thirty-two hundredths *bhagas* of a mandala.

**Q. How many mandalas does the moon traverse in an *abhivaddiya* month?**
**A.** It traverses fifteen mandalas, and sixty-three *bhagas* of a mandala.

**Q. How many mandalas does the sun traverse in an *abhivaddiya* month?**
**A.** It traverses sixteen mandalas, minus three *bhagas*, and two hundred and eighty-eight *bhagas* of a mandala.

**Q. How many mandalas does the *nakshatra* traverse in an *abhivaddiya* month?**
**A.** It traverses sixteen mandalas, and forty-one hundredths *bhagas*, fourteen and eighty-eight *bhagas* of a mandala.

**Q. How many mandalas does the moon traverse in a single *ahoratra*?**
**A.** It traverses half a mandala, minus thirty-one *bhagas*, and nine and fifteen hundredths *bhagas* of a mandala.

**Q. How many mandalas does the sun traverse in a single *ahoratra*?**
**A.** It traverses half a mandala.

**Q. How many mandalas does the *nakshatra* traverse in a single *ahoratra*?**
**A.** It traverses half a mandala, minus two *bhagas*, and seven and thirty-two hundredths *bhagas* of a mandala.

**Q. How many *ahoratras* does the moon take to traverse a single mandala?**
**A.** It takes two *ahoratras*, minus thirty-one *bhagas*, and four and forty-eight hundredths *bhagas* of an *ahoratra*.

**Q. How many *ahoratras* does the sun take to traverse a single mandala?**

The Sixteenth Praabhrut
Signs of Doshanai
87. 1. P. How are the signs of Doshanai? Tell me. U. They are Chandalesai.
2. P. Chandalesai and Doshanai, are they one in meaning or in signs? U. They are one in meaning and one in signs.
1. P. How are the signs of Sooralesa? Tell me. U. They are Sooralesai and Ayavei.
2. P. Sooralesai and Ayavei, are they one in meaning or in signs? U. They are one in meaning and one in signs.
1. P. How are the signs of Chhaya? Tell me. U. They are Chhaya and Andhkarai.
2. P. Chhaya and Andhkarai, are they one in meaning or in signs? U. They are one in meaning and one in signs.

**Seventy-seventh Prabhṛta**

In the context of the sun and moon, what are their distinct or shared characteristics? 
The answer: Indeed, these celestial bodies have certain qualities that can be elaborated upon as follows: 
1. At the very elemental level, the moon and sun share similarities, but as their journey progresses, they separate and exhibit their unique attributes; this has been stated. 
2. In brief spans of time, the moon and sun reflect differences in behavior; this has been noted. 
3. It is said that in a similar manner as above, so too can it be observed in the lower aspects and in the previously discussed twenty-five aspects of the Prabhṛta, up till the ultimate particle of existence according to scriptures. 
4. In brief: the moon and sun exhibit distinctions based on their phases, or qualitative aspects, unequally, and this is how they relate; this has been stated.
5. Hence, in a minute measure of time, the moon and sun also articulate their differences and shared characteristics; this is acknowledged. 
6. (Continued comments on the next page)

[Seventeenth Praabhrut]
[165]
They said thus: We are of this opinion and we declare - those Chandīma-Sūriya gods are Mahīḍḍiya, Mahājuiyā-Mahābala, Mahājasa, Mahāsaukka, Mahāṇubhāva. They are Vara Khatthadhara, Varamalladhara, Varagandhaghara, Varābharaṇadhara, and at the time of the Avvochittiṇayattthaya, some are born, some die, and the cycle of birth and death continues, thus we declare.

The eighteenth **Praabhrut** (chapter) **Chandayichchaina** (section) **Bhoomibhagao** (topic) **Uddhattam** (question) 89. **P. Ta Kaham Te Ucchatte Aahiteti Vadeja?** (How high are they?)
**U.** (Answer) **Tath Khulu Imaao Panavinsam Padivattio, Pannaattao, Tanjaha -** (There are nineteen opinions, as follows)
**Tathege Evam Ahansu - 1. To Egam Joyanasahas Suure Uddhe Ucchattenam, Divaddham Chaande, Ege Evam Asu.** (Some say that the Sun is one **Joyanasahas** (league) high, and the Moon is half that.)
**Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 2. Ta Do Joyanasahassai Suure Uddham Ucchattenam, Addatijai Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is two **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is one and a half that.)
**Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 3. Ta Tinni Joyanasahassai Suure Uddham Ucchattenam, Adhutthai Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is three **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is two and a half that.)
**Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 4. Ta Chattari Joyanasahassain Suure Uddham Ucchattenam, Addhapanamaai Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is four **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is three and a half that.)
**Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 5. Ta Panch Joyanasahassain Suure Uddhe Ucchattenam, Addhachhatthai Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is five **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is four and a half that.)
**Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 6. Ta Chha Joyanasahassai Suure Uddham Ucchattenam, Addhasattamaai Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is six **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is five and a half that.)
**Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 7. Ta Sattajoyanasahassain Suure Uddham Ucchattenam, Advatthamaim Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is seven **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is six and a half that.)
**Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 8. Ta Atth Joyanasahassai Suure Uddhe Ucchattenam, Addhanavamaim Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is eight **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is seven and a half that.)
**Ege Pun Evam Ahansu - 9. Ta Navajoyanasahassain Suure Uddham Ucchattenam, Addhadasamaim Chaande, Ege Evam Ahansu.** (Some say that the Sun is nine **Joyanasahas** high, and the Moon is eight and a half that.)

[The Eighteenth Prabhrita]
[167]
Some say thus - 10. The sun is ten thousand yojanas high in height, and the moon is half a yojana less, some say thus.
Some say thus - 11. The sun is eleven thousand yojanas high in height, and the moon is half a yojana less, some say thus.
These are to be understood in this manner - 12. The sun is twelve, and the moon is half a yojana less than thirteen, 13. The sun is thirteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than fourteen, 14. The sun is fourteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than fifteen, 15. The sun is fifteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than sixteen, 16. The sun is sixteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than seventeen, 17. The sun is seventeen, and the moon is half a yojana less than eighteen, 18. The sun is eighteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than nineteen, 19. The sun is nineteen, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty, 20. The sun is twenty, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-one, 21. The sun is twenty-one, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-two, 22. The sun is twenty-two, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-three, 23. The sun is twenty-three, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-four, 24. The sun is twenty-four, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-five, some say thus - 25. The sun is twenty-five thousand yojanas high in height, and the moon is half a yojana less than twenty-six, some say thus.
We, however, say thus - In this Ratnaprabha earth, the regions of the earth's surface extend to seventy-two hundred yojanas upwards, and they move about in the lower Taravimanas. From the Chandravimana, they rise up twenty yojanas upwards and move about in the upper Tararupas. Similarly, in the longitudinal and latitudinal dimensions, they move about in the innumerable Jyotisavisaya, the region of luminous bodies, extending to ten hundred yojanas in breadth. The reasons for the unequal and equal nature of the stars are ninety. There are, indeed, among the devas of the moon and the sun - some who are inferior to the Tararupas, some who are equal, and some who are equal as well as inferior to the Tararupas.

| Romanization (original) |
